Anthony's music career began in the late 1980s, singing in local bands and performing in nightclubs. He eventually formed a Latin R&B band called "The Latin Rascals" and released his debut album, "When the Night is Over," in 1991. The album gained moderate success, but it was his 1995 album "Otra Nota" that brought him widespread recognition.

Anthony's breakthrough came with his 1999 album "Marc Anthony," which included the hit single "I Need to Know." The album sold over 1 million copies in the United States and earned him two Grammy Awards, including Best Tropical Latin Album and Best Male Tropical Latin Performance.

Throughout his career, Anthony has experimented with various musical styles, incorporating elements of salsa, pop, rock, and R&B into his music. Anthony has won numerous awards and accolades, including four Grammy Awards, two Billboard Music Awards, and 13 Billboard Latin Music Awards. He has also won 17 Billboard Latin Awards, including the prestigious Billboard Latin Artist of the Decade Award (2000-2009).

In addition to his music career, Anthony is also known for his philanthropic work. He has performed at various benefit concerts and has supported charitable organizations, including the Make-A-Wish Foundation and the American Red Cross.

Throughout his illustrious career, Marc Anthony has become one of the most successful Latin artists of all time, with over 30 million records sold worldwide. His powerful voice, captivating stage presence, and versatility have made him a beloved figure in the music industry.
